* MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

In accordance with Section 68.73 of the RMP rule, the Site Responsible Engineer and Site Maintenance Manager have the responsibility for the overall mechanical integrity program, with specific emphasis on written procedures and maintenance specific training, the equipment and instrumentation inspection/test program and documentation, and equipment deficiency resolution as well as equipment initial design or modifications. Maintenance and Engineering with with Procurement to define and maintain appropriate quality assurance procedures for all types of equipment acquisitions/installations/repairs.

* MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

In accordance with Section 68.75 of the RMP rule, the Regional PSM Manager has the responsibility for the overall management of change (MOC) program; however, the Responsible Operations Manager has responsibility for final authorization of changes in order to ensure that the overall MOC program is effectively implemented in the process areas.

* PRE-STARTUP REVIEW

In accordance with Section 68.77 of the RMP rule, the Regional PSM Manager has the responsibility for the overall pre-startup review system, which is integrated into the MOC program. However, the Responsible Operations Manager has the primary responsibility for ensuring that this program is effectively implemented before affected operations begin.

* COMPLIANCE AUDIT

In accordance with Section 68.79 of the RMP rule, the Regional PSM Manager has the responsibility for ensuring that compliance audits regularly occur (and are documented) to verify that the prevention program is working and meets EPA/OSHA requirements. Each functional leader has responsibility for resolving any identified deficiency in their area.  

* INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

In accordance with Section 68.83 of the RMP rule, the Regional EHS has the responsibility for managing the incident investigatio

n program, including tracking resolution of investigation findings and recommendations. Part of this responsibility is ensuring that only trained personnel lead our investigations. The Regional PSM Manager will assist with process safety related incidents.  The Operations Manager has primary responsibility for ensuring that all incidents in their areas are reported and investigated, and the investigations findings are resolved, documented, and communicated to affected personnel.

* EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

In accordance with Section 68.83 of the RMP rule, the Regional PSM Manager, working with the Regional EHS Manager, and Responsible Operating Manager, has the responsibility of involving employees in the planning and implementation of the facility's prevention program elements.

* HOT WORK PERMITS

In accordance with Section 68.85 of the RMP rule, the Site Maintenance Manager, working closely with the Operations Manager and the Regional EHS Manager, have the responsibility of developing and maintaining the facility's hot work permit program.

* CONTRACTORS

In accordance with Section 68.87 of the RMP rule, the Site Maintenance Manager through use of a Contractor Specialist has the overall responsibility for the contractor management program; however, the Regional EHS Manager has responsiblilty for Contractor training and safety.  The Responsible Operations Manager is responsilbe for ensuring that the requirements of the program are implemented in their areas of responsibility.

* EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In accordance with Sections 68.90 and 68.95 of the RMP rule, the Regional EHS Manager is responsible for (1) designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility's emergency response plan, (2) ensuring that all associated training and drills are conducted and documented as necessary, (3) coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan, and (4) responding to local emergency planners/responders when question

s arise. This includes coordination and communication with the public and community and local emergency agencies. 

* RMPLAN PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION

The Regional PSM Manager is responsible for preparing and submitting the RMPlan for the facility as required under Sections 68.150 through 68.185 of the RMP rule.

RMPLAN COMMUNICATION

The Regional PSM Manager and the Regional EHS Manager have the responsibility of providing RMPlan information (other than the required EPA submission) to employees and the public as required under Section 68.210 of the RMP rule.  


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Each year the site is responsible for the development of an EHS improvment plan which includes process safety elements.  Improvements that are planned include but are not limited to conversion of TMA to Dimethylamine (DEA) as an inherently safer technology, increased emergency response training for Lucite employees to allow industrial fire-fighting and confined space rescue, and implementation of storage tank overfill protection.

LUCITE INTERNATIONAL SAFETY, HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY

We will drive continuous improvement in safety, health and environmental performance through our SHE Excellence programme.

In particular:

- Our actions will support the belief that all injuries, illnesses and incidents are preventable
- We will comply with all applicable laws, regulations and the industry's Responsible Care® initiative and take any additional measures considered necessary
- The SHE performance of contractors is an integral part of Lucite International's performance and will be managed to equivalent standards
- Our stewardship of SHE matters will be such that the community at large considers Lucite International a good neighbour
- We will pursue continuous improvement in our SHE performance and maximise our progress through the involvement of all employees
- All employees are responsible for the prevention of injuries, illnesses and environmental incidents. Accepting that responsibility is a condition of employment
- Line supervision will be accountable for SHE results and for the performance of their employees
- Employees will be thoroughly trained to work safely and to anticipate and prevent SHE incidents
- Audits will be conducted at all levels of the organisation to evaluate work practices and the effectiveness of the SHE programme
- All deficiencies will be corrected within an appropriate time frame
- All incidents, whether injury occurs or not, will be thoroughly investigated to identify root causes and prevent recurrence.


LUCITE INTERNATIONAL MEMPHIS FITE ROAD PLANT

The Lucite International Memphis Plant is a continuous chemical manufacturing facility that uses chemicals, including Trimethylamine (TMA) and Oleum, to produce Methyl Methacrylate (MMA). MMA is the major building block for a wide range of acrylic applications that are found in industries worldwide including: automotive, construction, retail and electronics. 
The Lucite Process Safety Manag

ement Program defines the accidental release prevention and emergency response policies as required by the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and corporate Lucite SHE standards. All policies meet the most stringent requirements of all applicable standards and regulations. 


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the last five years, the Lucite Memphis Plant has not experienced any accidental releases of RMP regulated chemicals, TMA and Oleum, which have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 


LUCITE ACCIDENT PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Lucite US Regional Manufacturing Director, has overall accountability for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner. This accountability includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program. To ensure that our program is appropriately applied and maintained, Manufacturing Director has delegated to a number of defined positions specific responsibilities in relation to the development, maintenance, implementation, and assurance of compliance with all requirements.  

These positions include:

The Responsible Site Executive - also known as the Site Manager, ensures adequate site resource and support in order to comply with all regulatory and corporate requirements
The Regional EHS Manager - oversees the systems and procedures for implementation of Occupational Safety, Health, and Environmental programs
The Regional Technology Director - oversees the development of technical documentation and analysis to identify and manage process hazards
The Regional PSM Manager - oversees the systems and procedures for implementation of the PSM and the risk management programs 
The Responsible Operating Manager - ensures local operating procedures ad

dress requirements and audits for compliance 
The Site Responsible Engineer/Responsible Engineer - manages and coordinates the implementation of policies and standards relating to integrity of assets
The Site Maintenance Manager - assists with inspection, testing, maintenance and repair of facility assets

For each of the following elements of the site risk management plan, the roles listed have been assigned responsibilities for the development, implementation, and integration of the specific EPA RMP/ OSHA PSM program element (where applicable) as required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule:

* HAZARD ASSESSMENTS

The Regional PSM Manager has the responsibility for (1) ensuring that offsite consequence analysis for each regulated process are consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68.39 and (2) selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility RMP as required under Section 68.165. The Regional PSM Manager also is responsible for ensuring that the accident history for each covered process is appropriately documented and maintained in accordance with Section 68.42 and 68.168 of the RMP rule.

* PREVENTION PROGRAMS

The Regional PSM Manager has the general responsibility for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant Program 3 prevention program that meets EPA RMP (Sections 68.65 through 68.87 of the RMP rule) and OSHA PSM requirements. Although the Regional PSM Manager has some specific individual responsibilities, many of the responsibilities for specific program elements are assigned to other positions.

* PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The responsibility for process safety information (PSI) (Section 68.65 of the RMP rule) is held by the Regional Technology Manager and the Site Responsible Engineer.  The information on the hazards and the technology of the process is the responsibility of the Regional Technology Manager.  Information on the equipment in the process is the

responsibility of the Site Responsible Engineer. 
 
* PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

In accordance with Section 68.67 of the RMP rule, the Responsible Operating Manager has ultimate responsibility for ensuring that process hazard analysis (PHAs) are scheduled, conducted, and documented by trained personnel for all regulated processes. The Regional Technology Manager selects PHA team leaders and ensures that they receive appropriate training before leading PHAs. Outside contractors may also be used to lead PHAs when appropriate. The Hazard Study Leader is responsible for (1) ensuring that the information and personnel necessary to conduct PHAs are available according to the PHA implementation schedule and (2) resolving recommendations that are assigned to their respective areas.  Recommendation s are assigned and tracked through the Corrective Actions Recordkeeping System (CARS).

* OPERATING PROCEDURES

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the Responsible Operating Manager has the responsibility for ensuring that complete and accurate operating procedures are in place for all regulated processes. In coordination with the Regional EHS Manager and the Site Maintenance Manager, the Responsible Operating Manager ensures that training is developed and delivered to maintain the facility's safe work practices for both operations and maintenance.

* TRAINING

In accordance with Section 68.71 of the RMP rule, the Regional PSM Manager in conjunction with the other functional managers have responsibility for (1) ensuring that employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and the associated processes and (2) ensuring that all facility employees receive and understand training in a safe work practices applicable to their jobs and (3) documenting the training.
